image.altText: A gold medal on a blue ribbon rests on a velvet cushion

items.synopsis: An NT auditor-general's report found the agency used taxpayer dollars to pay the consultant, who was hired to prepare nominations for the agency's current and previous board members.

title.children: Use of taxpayer-funded consultant to prepare OAM nominations for NT agency labelled 'bizarre'

image.altText: An older man wearing a blue suit and tie and glasses sits in a room with a portrait of Australia's Parliament House behind him.

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe has delivered his final public speech before handing over to Michele Bullock next week, admitting the central bank did "too much" after the pandemic "with the benefit of hindsight". Follow live.

title.children: Lowe admits RBA 'did too much' when it came to interest rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's reflect for a moment on a point Lowe made earlier in his speech about inflation. He noted that inflation had been wildly different during his time as RBA governor — and more than it had been in two decades. When he began as RBA governor, inflation was below that sweet spot of the 2-3% range we hear about so often, and as we know, inflation rose to its highest level in more than 30 years recently. Overall, he said underlying inflation was averaging 2.7% in his seven-year term, while headline inflation was around 3%. But he does expect that inflation will swing more wildly than it has ever before because of the increased prevalence of supply shocks (like what we saw during the pandemic) plus c limate change, energy transitions and changing demographics. "My view is that it will be difficult to return to the earlier world in which inflation tracked in a very narrow range," he said. That doesn't mean the end of inflation targeting, however — he remains a strong advocate for that 2-3% range.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lowe expects inflation will be more volatile in the years ahead

inflation
He noted that
inflation had been wildly different
during his time as RBA governor — and more than it had been in two decades.
When he began as RBA governor, inflation was below that sweet spot of the 2-3% range we hear about so often, and as we know, inflation rose to its highest level in more than 30 years recently.
Overall, he said
underlying inflation was averaging 2.7%
in his seven-year term, while

But he does expect that

because of the increased prevalence of

"My view is that

in which inflation tracked in a very narrow range," he said.
That doesn't mean the end of inflation targeting, however — he remains a strong advocate for that 2-3% range.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And with that, the speech by the outgoing RBA governor has come to an end, as has the formalities that were happening at the end. It was a pretty wide-ranging speech — after all, he has spent the past seven years in the job, and has a career spanning decades at the central bank. To summarise it, in case you're just joining us: Philip Lowe conceded some mistakes in the top job, claimed some major successes, and also warned of the changing nature of inflation. If you were watching or listening, what did you make of it? What is your reaction to his admission that the RBA 'did too much'? Let me know your thoughts by hitting the blue button at the top of the blog, and I'll share some of them soon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: That's it for Philip Lowe's final speech as RBA governor

children.content: And with that, the speech by the outgoing RBA governor has come to an end, as has the formalities that were happening at the end.
It was a pretty wide-ranging speech — after all, he has spent the past seven years in the job, and has a career spanning decades at the central bank.
To summarise it, in case you're just joining us: Philip Lowe conceded some mistakes in the top job, claimed some major successes, and also warned of the changing nature of inflation.
If you were watching or listening, what did you make of it? What is your reaction to his admission that the RBA 'did too much'?
Let me know your thoughts by hitting the blue button at the top of the blog, and I'll share some of them soon.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Bill Evans from Westpac gets the final question, who repeats a comment made by Alan Greenspan, a former chair of the US Federal Reserve. Greenspan said "I'll tell you when I get there" when he was asked what the neutral interest rate was. Evans asked for Lowe's take on the question — here's how he replied: "I'm going to disappoint you," he begins. "I can never understand Greenspan's perspective here. "We're making really important decisions on behalf of the country that can be unpopular, they affect the distribution of income, so they're really important decisions. "And given that, we need, I think, we need to be as accountable as we can and explain our decisions as clearly as we can. "And the reasons why we taking those decisions and the trade offs we're managing. 
I cannot see how can help the situation by being unclear. "At various points in time, I've struggled to be as clear as I wanted to be, but I've always sought to explain things as clearly as possible. "Australian should expect us to take important decisions, we affect all your lives, and you have a right to know why we take those decisions and how we manage them. "In terms of the neutral interest rate, I'm going to leave that to my successor."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The final question to Lowe: What is the neutral interest rate?

children.content: Bill Evans from Westpac gets the final question, who repeats a comment made by Alan Greenspan, a former chair of the US Federal Reserve.
Greenspan said "I'll tell you when I get there" when he was asked what the neutral interest rate was.
Evans asked for Lowe's take on the question — here's how he replied:
"I'm going to disappoint you," he begins.
"I can never understand Greenspan's perspective here.
"We're making really important decisions on behalf of the country that can be unpopular, they affect the distribution of income, so they're really important decisions.
"And given that, we need, I think, we need to be as accountable as we can and explain our decisions as clearly as we can.

"And the reasons why we taking those decisions and the trade offs we're managing. 
I cannot see how can help the situation by being unclear.
"At various points in time, I've struggled to be as clear as I wanted to be, but I've always sought to explain things as clearly as possible.
"Australian should expect us to take important decisions, we affect all your lives, and you have a right to know why we take those decisions and how we manage them.
"In terms of the neutral interest rate, I'm going to leave that to my successor."

image.altText: A page from eHarmony’s website shows examples of its ‘free dating’ statements

items.synopsis: eHarmony is hit with a lawsuit by the consumer watchdog, alleging the dating site breached Australian consumer law by making misleading statements about the pricing, renewal and cancellation of its memberships.

title.children: eHarmony sued over alleged 'subscription trap' and other 'misleading' statements

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce reportedly jets off with a substantial amount of cash and Qantas shares in his portfolio — but valid questions are being asked about whether he is entitled to all of it.

title.children: Qantas' board is under enormous pressure to scrap Alan Joyce's final payout. Could they actually do it?

image.altText: A black and white photo of a woman outdoors.

items.synopsis: For three months, this Swiss adventurer walked alone for 1,500 kilometres through parts of the Nullarbor, Great Victoria Desert and Gibson Desert. She says Australia is now "in her blood".

title.children: While trekking in remote Australia, Sarah didn't speak for six weeks. She says it is 'magical'

image.altText: Relaxed anonymous male teenager texting on mobile phone. His face is obscured by his hands and mobile in front of him.

items.synopsis: Recently emojis have landed some people in legal trouble in courts around the world. So what constitutes crossing the line?

title.children: Don't underestimate the legal implications of a thumbs-up emoji — it cost a Canadian man $90,000

image.altText: A woman in a yellow jacket, a woman in a navy jacket sit on a green bench seat while a man stands and shouts

items.synopsis: The heated discussion over why Qatar Airways' bid to increase flights to Australia was rejected has left the government juggling excess political baggage, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: 'C'mon, guys, you know people are watching': When all hell broke loose in Question Time, an independent stood up

image.altText: Catherine King stands at lecturn in front of airport signage

items.synopsis: Catherine King says the 2020 incident was one factor in her decision to reject Qatar's application to increase its flights to major Australian airports, but that no single issue swayed her one way or the other.

title.children: 'Absolute nonsense': Transport minister rejects claims Qatar flights would make big difference to ticket prices

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Xi Jinping smiling and shaking hands

items.synopsis: The prime minister says he will travel to China to mark the 50th anniversary of former PM Gough Whitlam's historic visit to the country, also becoming the first Australian leader to go to China since 2016.

title.children: Albanese confirms China trip for later this year

image.altText: A young man with a beard.

items.synopsis: A major police operation is underway in Kellerberrin, with people being asked to stay indoors after a person was shot dead at a manufacturing plant.

title.children: Active shooter in camouflage gear on loose, police manhunt underway after WA grain silo worker shot dead

image.altText: A woman crouching looking up at a furry animal and patting it as its held by another person.

items.synopsis: The environment minister hopes to avoid more species becoming extinct due to feral cats, as a draft plan to contain the animals is released for consultation.

title.children: Federal government declares 'war' on feral cats

image.altText: A globe centred on Australia showing rainfall anomaly patterns, mostly red to indicate dryness. A date indicates August 2023

items.synopsis: It’s the phenomenon behind some of Australia’s hottest, driest years, and climate change could be making it more extreme. Here’s why that doesn’t guarantee catastrophe this year — or in the future.

title.children: An El Niño could be declared as early as next week: This is what it looks like when it forms

image.altText: A group of men wearing suits

items.synopsis: Police allege the 61-year-old concealed a serious indictable offence after the incident on Friday night, where two people were killed in Sydney's south-west.

title.children: Alleged driver's father charged with hindering investigation into fatal Heckenberg crash

image.altText: three men at sea.

items.synopsis: Australian Border Force officers have greeted three sailors who had to be rescued from a sinking catamaran in the Coral Sea.

title.children: Rescued sailors make it back to port after inflatable boat savaged by sharks

image.altText: a small shark out of water

items.synopsis: Three sailors attempting a round-the-world voyage have been rescued after their boat was attacked off the coast of Cairns and began to sink. It's suspected their craft was set upon by cookiecutter sharks.

title.children: How a 40-centimetre shark brought a catamaran's round-the-world voyage to a halt

image.altText: Person holds woman who is emotional behind them is debris of homes

items.synopsis: Large swathes of the US, Europe and Asia are battling concurrent natural disasters, leaving hundreds dead and thousands displaced. Here's the latest from across the world.

title.children: Fires, cyclones and heatwaves: Disasters felt around the globe amid hottest northern summer

image.altText: A man in a dark corner putting his hands on a red brick wall and his feet on the opposite white wall floating above ground

items.synopsis: Police are flooding a search zone of increasingly worried residents in Philadelphia after revealing a killer escaped prison by scaling a wall and going undetected for an hour.

title.children: Murderer 'crab-walked' himself out of US prison, authorities reveal as seven-day manhunt drags on

image.altText: A smiling young man in a racing driver's jumpsuit holds a trophy and raises his finger in triumph.

items.synopsis: Formula 500 driver Luke Nardini has been charged with manslaughter following a crash that occurred while he was allegedly driving on the wrong side of a US highway. His mother says her son is deeply saddened by the "terrible" incident.

title.children: Community devastated as Australian racing driver charged over deadly crash in California

image.altText: Gary Mitchell and his students post for a 1972 school photograph.

items.synopsis: A Board of Inquiry looking into child sexual abuse allegations will focus on three teachers, including convicted paedophile Gary Arthur Mitchell, and 18 government schools in Victoria.

title.children: Victorian inquiry into historical child sexual abuse to investigate three teachers and 18 schools

image.altText: A woman in a dressing gown sits on a hospital chair.

items.synopsis: A cancer patient at Royal Hobart Hospital says she got a letter with her dinner asking patients to consider leaving to help ease demand for beds.

title.children: Hospital asks inpatients to consider leaving because it's 'very busy'

image.altText: A sinkhole in a street.

items.synopsis: A large sinkhole in the middle of an Adelaide street is believed to have been caused by a break in the sewer main, causing a malodorous mess to flood into surrounding properties.

title.children: Sinkhole stink as sewage floods properties in suburban Adelaide street

image.altText: Kourtney Kardashian Barker's foetal pregnancy Instagram post

items.synopsis: The reality television personality says she walked out of hospital 'with my baby boy in my tummy' and a new understanding for mothers who had dealt with difficult pregnancies.

title.children: Kourtney Kardashian Barker says she has new respect for mothers after 'urgent fetal surgery'

image.altText: Two police officers take a selfie photo with a smiling man and woman next to the ocean at sunset.

items.synopsis: After hearing a scream, Eric Krins and Maree Pearson did not hesitate to rush to the aid of the 67-year-old woman at a remote WA beach.

title.children: Byron Bay couple become holiday heroes with daring rescue of Ningaloo snorkeller 80m from shore

image.altText: a baby maugean skate in front of a light, looks translucent and glows red

items.synopsis: The maugean skate, a species of ray, is only found in one waterway and it is thought there are fewer than 1,000 left.

title.children: It may not have the friendliest face, but $2.1m has just been spent to save it

image.altText: the front of a house and carport, with the ocean seen behind it

items.synopsis: The rise of short-term holiday rentals like Airbnb and Stayz have changed the way we travel, but they've also faced backlash over concerns they're driving rents up and exacerbating housing shortages in cities around the world.

title.children: Short-term rentals are often blamed for exacerbating the housing crisis. Now the regulation is catching up

image.altText: A Marine Rescue officer in a boat looks out over a lake through a pair of binoculars.

items.synopsis: The men, both aged 73, were expected to return from their trip last night.

title.children: Body recovered, boat found during search for pair of missing fishermen

image.altText: Natalie Sinclair sitting at a table, reaching towards bottles of Hysone and Hydrocortisone.

items.synopsis: The drug Natalie Sinclair takes to keep her alive is among hundreds of medications that have been in short supply in Australia, but advocates fear stockholding laws for suppliers are having little impact on the ground.

title.children: More than 400 medicines are in 'short supply' in Australia. Advocates are calling for change

image.altText: A sweaty Daniil Medvedev wraps a towel around his head with a look of relief on his face.

items.synopsis: Daniil Medvedev says hot and humid conditions at the US Open have the potential to be "dangerous" for players after he booked a berth in the men's semifinals, where he will face Carlos Alcaraz.

title.children: 'One player is going to die': Medvedev issues warning about stifling US Open heat

image.altText: A car is engulfed in flames in the bush.

items.synopsis: Andrew Johns has felt the devastating impact of crime firsthand and is questioning his faith in community spirit, amid concerns his hometown of Gunnedah has a crime problem.

title.children: Firefighter called to blaze only to discover his own vehicle was alight

image.altText: A plane flying in a blue sky.

items.synopsis: It costs $150,000 to become a pilot, but juniors would be "lucky" to earn $35,000 in their first year, according to the Australian and International Pilots Association.

title.children: Claims low pay keeping 'smart young people' from becoming pilots, causing shortages in besieged industry

image.altText: A home under construction with timber frame and one external brick wall.

items.synopsis: WA home builder BGC is set to be hit with a massive class action as potentially thousands of disgruntled home owners seek compensation after waiting years for their homes to be built.

title.children: Huge class action set to be launched against Perth builder that left customers waiting years for new homes

image.altText: A luxury cruise on the ocean ship beneath a clear sky.

items.synopsis: MS Caledonian Sky was arrested off Roebuck Bay late last month over a separate dispute. Now an international union alleges its crew was underpaid.

title.children: Luxury cruise ship detained off WA now at centre of wage theft allegations

image.altText: Brown haired boy wears red check shirt, smiles slightly, acne on face,wall with Indigenous hand art behind.

items.synopsis: A teenager is among many in the outback benefiting from a program that combines Western science with Aboriginal cultural teachings to improve sleep health for Indigenous people.

title.children: John felt 'violent and angry all the time'. Then he had his first good night's sleep

image.altText: Garry Ringrose screams as he runs with the ball with three France players on the ground behind him

items.synopsis: Opta statistics say there are four clear favourites heading into the Rugby World Cup — but there's a major loophole that could mean the Wallabies have a deep run in the tournament, despite being ranked as major outsiders.

title.children: Who is going to win the Rugby World Cup? Opta says it's a four-horse race
